awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: NRT: Cyber-Physical-Social System for Understanding and Thwarting the Illicit Economy
awd_abstract_narration:
The negative societal impacts of counterfeiting are widespread, touching nearly every economic sector, including health care, and threatening our national security. The explosion of the illicit economy can be traced to the growth in online commerce and an "abuse ecosystem" of rogue internet actors, direct-to-consumer courier delivery services, and the lack of product protective measures to counteract counterfeiting. This increase is further fueled by new digital tools available to counterfeiters, such as higher resolution digital printers.  This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) collaborative award to four South Dakota universities (South Dakota School of Mines and Technology, University of South Dakota, South Dakota State University and Dakota State University) will provide graduate students with the scientific knowledge and professional skills and training needed to become next-generation leaders in the fight against counterfeiting.  Participants will receive professional and leadership training within the framework of a unique cyber-physical-social model.  This model takes a comprehensive approach that factors in not only the technical aspects of the cyber strategies and physical methods used to combat counterfeiting, but also whether these strategies and methods are compatible with human behavior. This model will allow trainees to solve complex problems, where the solutions must tightly integrate cyber, physical, and social interactions in real-time. The project anticipates training forty-five (45) Ph.D. and M.S. students, including thirty (30) funded trainees, from physical science, engineering, computer science and behavioral science.

Trainees will be immersed in a mission-driven framework to conduct research across three collaborative research areas: (1) nano-photonics for anti-counterfeiting and authentication, (2) identification and detection of counterfeit chemicals/pharmaceutics, and (3) internet-based investigations, digital forensics and the cyber/physical interface.  The education and training program encompasses two overarching themes: (1) active learning and (2) translational understanding of the illicit economy and the technologies needed to mitigate it.  Embedded within these themes is a leadership component involving explicit training in entrepreneurship and communication.  Additional highlights of the program include an internship experience with leading private/public sector organizations that will allow trainees to quickly gain a contextual understanding of the counterfeiting epidemic and technology landscape; an integrated and multi-level mentorship program to provide trainees with ongoing feedback and guidance, promoting retention and timely matriculation; and engagement of a broader audience through creation of outreach and certificate programs for the general public.  These program features will ensure trainees emerge as highly-trained STEM leaders, engaged in a wide array of important interconnected issues, and able to tackle complex socio-technical challenges. 

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training. The program is dedicated to effective training of STEM graduate students in high priority interdisciplinary research areas through comprehensive traineeship models that are innovative, evidence-based, and aligned with changing workforce and research needs.

This proposal is co-funded by the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR). EPSCoR co-funds projects that advance excellence in science and engineering research and education. Fostering sustainable increases in research, education, and training capacity and competitiveness within EPSCoR jurisdictions will enable EPSCoR participants to have increased engagement in areas supported by the NSF.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The NRT program was designed to foster the development and implementation of transformative strategies in anti-counterfeiting and the fight against the illicit economy within STEM graduate education. The program embraced an interdisciplinary approach, training students to work collaboratively in teams, honing their ability to communicate effectively and achieve scientific goals. These skills are essential for success in both academic and non-academic careers. Additionally, the program emphasized the development of professional skills (e.g., seminars, external partnerships) to further prepare students for a wide range of career opportunities.

The NRT program spanned the state of South Dakota and included four of the six state regental higher education institutions including Dakota State University (DSU), South Dakota Mines (SDM), South Dakota State University (SDSU), and University of South Dakota (USD). Tables 1 and 2 show the Trainee degree programs. The Trainees collectively presented a total of 132 posters and/or papers during their time as graduate students. The Trainees collectively wrote a total of 51 publications (articles, book chapters) during their time as graduate students. 

Broader Impacts

Trainees who completed a master’s degree reported completing their degree in one to four years with an average of two years. Trainees who already had a master’s degree when beginning their Ph.D. at one of the South Dakota institutions reported completing their degree in three to six years. The Cyber Defense Ph.D. completion was less than the natural science and engineering degrees. Trainees who completed both their master’s and Ph.D. degrees reported finishing within three to six years. The Trainees reported the NRT program did not prolong their degree completion. 100% of the Trainees were retained in the program, or have graduated. 

Twenty one faculty from twelve different disciplines mentored Trainees. Two courses were developed for the NRT program – Cyber-Physical-Social System for Understanding & Thwarting the Illicit Economy and Science Communication.  In additions, Trainees attended an Entrepreneurship Bootcamp.

The program had 70% of trainees from underrepresented groups in STEM. 61% of the trainees were female and 13% of the trainees are ethnic minorities. The program was collaborative across four universities that had different Carnegie Classifications (R2 and M2), each with a distinct mission. The trainees came from 10 different programs, each with a unique unit context. 

Intellectual Merit

Trainees conducted transdisciplinary research around cyber-physical-social aspects of the illicit economy. 

Physical

  • Estimating the Occurrence/Prevalence of the Risk of Fossil Poaching in Fossil-Rich Geologic Units of the Northern Mid-Western States, USA
  • Energetic and Optically Responsive Cargo in Porous Walled Hollow Glass Microspheres for Anti-Counterfeiting Applications
  • Development of a Chromatographic Method to Authenticate Aspirin Brands
  • Non-Powder Application of Upconverting Nanoparticles for Fingerprint Development
  • Synthesis, Characterization, and Application of Novel Surface-Eroding Anhydrides
  • Geofingerprinting Coltan Using Handheld Spectroscopy Devices
  • Inkjet Printing of SERS-based Inks for Covert Anti-Counterfeiting Labels
  • Coordination Complexes Featuring Bidentate κN, κI-8-Iodoquinoline and Assessment of the Efficacy of Chloro[2-(Mesityl(Quinolin-8-Yl-κN)Boryl]-3,5-Dimethyl-Phenyl}Methyl-κC)Palladium(Ii) Toward the Activation of C-F Bonds

Cyber

  • A Framework for Identifying Host-based Artifacts in Dark Web Investigations
  • Man or Machine: Processes and Implications of Artificial Fingerprint Generation
  • A Class of Regression Models for Pairwise Comparisons of Forensic Handwriting Comparison Systems
  • What is Explainable AI?: A Focus on Ethical Theory
  • Convolutional Autoencoder Neural Network Design Evluation for an Anomaly Detection Subsystem in Autonomous Spacecraft Computer Vision Systems
  • An Open-Source Intelligence Model for Proactive Defense of Cyber Attacks within Critical Infrastructure-
  • A Data Privacy Model for Education Systems
  • A Digital Forensics Model to Investigate Malware Using Generative AI- Shaw

Social

  • Anti-Counterfeiting Warnings: Do They Influence Consumer Behavior and Perception of Overt Indicators?
  • The Impact of Immersive VR Verses Desktop VR Technologies on Learning Attainment and Sense of Presence

Last Modified: 09/03/2024
Modified by: Brian A Logue
